summary: Wrongfully accused of murdering his wife, Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford) escapes from the law in an attempt to find her killer and clear his name. Pursuing him is a team of U.S. marshals led by Deputy Samuel Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones), a determined detective who will not rest until Richard is captured. As Richard leads the team through a series of intricate chases, he discovers the secrets behind his wife's death and struggles to expose the killer before it is too late.

reviews.content:
Cat and mouse thriller for an archetypal thriller!

Director Andrew Davis' action thriller The Fugitive (1993) holds up with tense encounters and suspense chases around Chicago. Davis keeps you engaged with intense direction that has sweeping wide shots of Chicago's cityscape from cinematographer Michael Chapman. I love the close-ups like in the iconic sewer scene, where Tommy Lee Jones shouts, "I don't care!" Andrew Davis delivers a truly timeless thriller with chases, distractions, and twists galore.

Writers Jeb Stuart and David Twohy adapted Roy Huggins' novel for an intricate crime narrative about a murdered wife, a one armed assailant, an obsessed marshal, and a desperate innocent man on the run. The Fugitive lets us sympathize with Kimble because he's innocent and he's a doctor who is always trying to help others. It's a great story told in an elegant and effective way. The Fugitive is exciting, emotional, and intense fun.

Harrison Ford is likable as the fugitive in question Dr. Richard Kimble. His clear love for his wife, care for patients, and patience in tracking down the real killer while evading police is gripping. Ford finds an emotional heart to Kimble. Tommy Lee Jones is outstanding and hilarious as the gruff and persistent Deputy U.S. Marshal Sam Gerard. His fastidious nature makes him a pitbull of a man and pursuer. Jones is so entertaining and my favorite as of The Fugitive. It's easy to see why he won Best Supporting Actor despite being up against legendary performances from Ralph Fiennes in Schindler's List or Pete Postlethwaite within In the Name of the Father.

Sela Ward is sympathetic and pretty as Helen Kimble. Joe Pantoliano is a riot as the smart-mouthed Deputy U.S. Marshal Cosmo Renfro. Andreas Katsulas is creepy as the one armed man Fredrick Sykes. Jeroen Krabbé is sleazy and friendly alike as Dr. Charles Nichols. Daniel Roebuck as Deputy U.S. Marshal Bobby Biggs, Tom Wood as Deputy U.S. Marshal Noah Newman, L. Scott Caldwell as Deputy U.S. Marshal Erin Poole, and Johnny Lee Davenport as Deputy U.S. Marshal Henry are all a scream opposite Tommy Lee Jones' fiery orders and steadfast command.

Julianne Moore is gorgeous and playful as the smart and observant Dr. Anne Eastman in an early career role for her. Jane Lynch is considerate as the helpful Dr. Kathy Wahlund. Dick Cusack makes a nice appearance as Kimble's Attorney Walter Gutherie. Nick Searcy is great as the underhanded Sheriff Rawlins. Neil Flynn has a memorable cameo as the unfortunate Transit Cop.

Editors Dennis Virkler, Dov Hoenig, David Finfer, Richard Nord, Don Brochu, and Dean Goodhill worked together to splice together all the Chicago footage to ensure intense chases felt exhilarating. They really cover all their bases with flashbacks and bits of information getting a quick cut to jog the viewer's memory, so that we can always follow along. Production designer J. Dennis Washington creates hospitals, law offices, and homes stuffed with realistic props from set decorator Rick Gentz.

Composer James Newton Howard wrote a thrilling and powerful film score for The Fugitive. The main theme is so exciting with intense string arrangements. Costume designers Aggie Guerard Rodgers and Linda Henrikson create tons of marshal's outfits and runaway disguises. Makeup artists Peter Robb-King, Rodger Jacobs, and Pat Gerhardt create several visual changes and facial makeup choices to disguise Harrison Ford and give him injuries. Hairstyling from Kathe Swanson, Dominic Mango, and Mary Buono give Ford dye jobs and different cuts for unique hair disguises throughout The Fugitive.

In all, The Fugitive is worth seeing and rewatching time and time again.
a great time, a fleshed out story, and great writing and performances from every actor on the screen.

This 30 year old film still holds up pretty well. The plot is good and intense, Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are great in their roles. The only "bad" thing about this film is the "Peter Pan over the dam" scene, an iconic moment with a hilariously bad and obvious dummy. Definitely worth a watch if you haven't seen this before.

It's hard to believe that this action-packed thriller was considered Oscar-worthy, and even harder to believe that Tommy Lee Jones landed a Best Supporting Actor win for his role in it. The Fugitive is well-crafted owing to its gripping plot, fantastic cast, and superb production value but it's not Oscar material by today's standards. Harrison Ford gave one the most intense performances of his career, succeeding in keeping viewers on the edge of their seat. Although the ending is predictable, The Fugitive is stimulating as well as entertaining which makes it superior in its genre.

Undeniable great storyline and cast with an epic movie worthy of high praises. No matter how many times we watch it, its always enjoyable and captivating. Bring on the popcorn, chips and pop and sit down to be entertained.

This an excellent movie, The Fugitive, 1993 film based on a TV series with same name in 1963 by Roy Huggins is directed by Andrew Davis...with story and co-writer by David Twohy...and having a strong casting, such as Harrison Ford, Tommy Lee Jones, and actresses, Sela Ward as well as Julianne Moore ...
A classic to be sure. Everyone needs to see it at least once. A fun thriller that is definitely worth the watch.
Harrison Fords best independent work away from the franchises. Awesome watch and great story. Great acting.

An action thriller that is hard not to love. With Harrison Ford giving a sympathetic performance. As man wrongfully accused of murdering his wife. On the run from a gun ho U.S. Marshall (Tommy Lee Jones). Who is determined to catch him.

What a fantastic movie! I can't believe that it has taken so long for me to watch The Fugitive. The plot is simple and direct, the script is equally slick and the performances are excellent. I was particularly surprised by Harrison Ford. He has always been an average performer in my opinion, but his acting chops are on full display in this film, especially in the opening sequence. Tommy Lee Jones is also great in this movie, with his performance more genuine than later movies (when he is a curmudgeon).

From start to finish, I was glued to the action and fully invested in what happened to Dr. Kimble. Though the plot is fairly predictable, the story is highly captivating.

Best Character: Dr. Richard Kimble
Best Scene: The final cop car scene.
Best Quote: "I thought you didn't care." - Richard "I don't." - Gerard

I'd say 2/3 of this film really stands tall above nearly all the thrillers and crime dramas of the 90's. For a film that has fairly strong plotting, the showdown/climax and "reveal" is a bit generic and lacks the energy the film was brimming with in the first and second act.
Best of Movies/TV Series Collection

A thriller from when the genre specification really kept its promise, and the film actually was thrilling. This one is guaranteed to keep you awake and make you feel the edge of your seat. It's still exciting after nearly 30 years, and modern film makers have a brilliant study object.
Unfortunately I consider the movie quite boring

"The Fugitive" is a first-rate thriller from the 90s. I think the first act of this movie is awesome and really had me on my toes. I feel like it mixes goofier elements with stuff that's super serious pretty well. I think Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are consistently fun to watch and I was always interested to see where it would go next. I think my main issue with the movie was the big revelations that happen near the end. To me, the mystery element unfolded in a kind of underwhelming way that took me out of it a bit. Nonetheless, the thrills are there throughout and the intrigue is still pretty solid when it's building up. Overall, it is a solid movie that is worth checking out and an impressive movie of its era.

This movie never stops moving, Harrison Ford plays it smart as Richard Kimble and Tommy Lee Jones plays it tough and witty as Sam Gerard. This movie will stand as an amazing crime thriller. Apart from the final showdown, I thought this movie was perfect.
A very suspenseful action flick. Harrison Ford did a fantastic job as the titular fugituve and Tommy Lee jones was great as usual.  The mystery is also well written.
Just a good story and with well done action. Great pacing. Good storytelling. 100 percent worth a watch.

Hitchcock may have invented the "wrong man" genre, but Andy Davis lucked out with this cast, script and year of production (5 years later and they would have used crappy CG instead of the incredible, real life train crash). The straight down aerial shots in this film really started a trend that is popular to this day. Tommy Lee Jones' most memorable and iconic role and dialogue by far, and the scenario fits Ford's personality perfectly. Supporting cast are perfect, and Chicago is almost a character itself in the film. You're rooting for both the chaser and the chasee, so you don't get tired of rewatching a movie like this.
Great Just Great, although from 29 years ago, still fresh. Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are great!!

An exciting thriller that scores by expertly combining a kinetic chase with a thorny mystery, and is well served by two charismatic leads giving the sort of performances they do best. It's also one of those rare films that use flashbacks both sparingly and effectively, without sacrificing the breathless momentum of the plot - even the way the groundwork is established in the first few minutes is frantic.
Have to watch it every time it's on TV!
Classic Ford. A thrilling story with the right amount of close calls and twists.
It does not deliver as much as I thought it would, but it is a movie worth watching. I just feel like every part of it, the thrills, action, etc. have all been done better elsewhere.

I'll admit, I've been waiting to put this on my list of recommendations (I know I've mentioned it in passing). The Fugitive is the benchmark all thrillers should aspire to, and although I've stated The Bourne Supremacy is the pinnacle of the modern thriller, Paul Greengrass' masterpiece owes a debt to Andrew Davis unbeatable beauty. Harrison Ford is astonishing, (although he was ignored by the academy who failed to rectify their previous mistake when they failed to award him Best Actor for Witness [1985]) and Tommy Lee Jones (who did bag an Oscar) plays off him superbly, in one of the great thrillers.
The Fugitive biggest asset is it's pacing, it manages to hold the viewers attention for the entire 2 hours of run time.
Great film with great performances from Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones. This film has a really good soundtrack as well and keeps the viewer on edge as a conspiracy is unraveled.
I know it has that Dances With Wolves vibe but so does Avatar. I say Jolly Good
I was first in the door opening day in Fresno CA  Love the film  Tommy deserved his Oscar

Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones race around in circles for this memorable early '90s cat-and-mouse blockbuster, skillfully adapting and modernizing a four-season television series from thirty years prior. The Fugitive doesn't fool around, racing through dozens of heavy plot points in the first hour without feeling overwhelming or hyperactive. It's a succinct, condensed version of a once-sprawling serial, one which trims away the obligatory TV padding without skipping any good bits.

While it's trucking through those establishing shots, the story is a whiplash stunner; in the blink of an eye, we see our protagonist as a respected physician, grieving husband, bewildered murder suspect, sentenced convict, opportunistic escapee and outdoor survivalist, with one particularly well-executed train derailment thrown in to really kick off all the turmoil. Almost by necessity, the second act slows down to focus on the chase, balancing Ford's attempts to lay low with Jones's top-of-the-food-chain detective work. That performs well, too, a firm gear-shift from the opening salvo's manic mayhem (one that's certainly assisted by its two phenomenal cornerstone stars), though it does lose its way as all the different points converge and the moment of resolution draws near. By contrast, the ending falls more on the bland, derivative side; careful suspense cast aside in favor of a big chair-tossing, pipe-swinging, rock'em'sock'em finale. These scenes are inoffensive, but a decided step down from what we'd seen and felt just prior. Put it this way: I still vividly recalled the bus crash and dam jump, decades after I last saw them. I'd forgotten all about the climactic rooftop fist fight.

While the gettin's good, it's real good. A fairly simple premise with plenty of intrigue and gray morality, a tight script, more than one all-decade action set, a super-sized portion of Tommy Lee Jones intensity and lots and lots of chances for grim Harrison Ford to glance worriedly over his shoulder. Maybe not perfect, but it still holds up.
One of the best action thriller film with really outstanding performance and great directing.

Two fantastic lead performances by Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones (and even Joe Pantoliano), strong direction and a fast-paced narrative with a compelling mystery to offer thanks to wonderful writing, The Fugitive is a phenomenal watch from start to end and one of the most thrilling and most exciting films i've ever watched. Absolute must-see for anyone into movies and who likes action and thriller films.

Fucking loved it.  Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones play off of each other so well! 
 Definitely try to see it.

In an era where action films are defined by gratuitous gunfire and flat characters, The Fugitive feels like a breath of fresh air. The chase sequences are gripping, and the film as a whole leaves one feeling more than satisfied by the end.
A fun action/crime movie with Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones pulling off nice performances, had a really basic and great story, and went in a fast pace.
A movie that will keep you awake till the end
Love Harrison Ford here.  Great editing and I think the action sequences were supreme :)

The fugitive is great. Harrison Ford gives a really good performance. The main storyline is very engaging and the film stands to have a very strong first and 2nd act. Even though the third act was a bit weak it was still a great time. 

SCORE: A-

A fantastic 90s action-thriller featuring a brilliantly set-up game of cat and mouse between Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones, The Fugitive is the kind of movie that I will always want to rewatch whenever it appears on TV (and it does fairly frequently).

There's no other way to put it, this is a terrific film! I dare to say that this is one of the best action movies ever made. It's exciting, very captivating from beginning to end, it's nail-biting and suspenseful. Those chase scenes are full of adrenaline. It features a memorable score, which sometimes helps to set the mood. And the acting is unforgettable. While Tommy Lee Jones won an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor in this film, I think it was Harrison Ford who gave a great performance. He plays a character that we feel for. Overall, The Fugitive is one of the greatest movies that I've seen in a while, it's a great classic. Recommended!!
Another masterclass film that has Harrison Ford.
Incredible action sequences. Thrilling! Smartly woven with intriguing characters.
A perfect movie in every sense
An honesty really entertaining movie that I should I seen much earlier.

Gripping and intense. "The Fugitive" is a movie that never failed to fascinate me with its captivating thriller and impressive directing. This chase thriller of a film will keep you interested from start to end. Unfortunately, It doesn't possess anything more to the story than just a heart-stabbing thriller.
One of the most beutifull movies I have ever seen

The Fugitive is pure entertainment. Harrison Ford seems to be widely known as Han Solo and Indiana Jones but I feel like this character he portrays really shows how great of an actor he is. Tommy Lee Jones is also great, although his best supporting actor win is rubbish. But at some point Ford running away from the authorities starts to feel rehashed. In that sense its slightly overlong. Its not just entertaining but it happens to be a very well crafted thriller.
Pretty good in 2020. Nice developing story.
Well made remake that captures the thrill of the show.
It's very remarkable that the world where the story is set, is made more real by little details planted everywhere.
Very simple story but very effective as a thriller...harrison ford and tommy lee jones play very good parts...enjoyed
Pure action and writing gold.
The Fugitive is a tight, thrilling, action film about an innocent man on the run from the law. Harrison Ford shines in possibly his best film of the 90's

This taut action-thriller is a rare example of a film exceeding the level of it's television roots. Fast-paced and frantic, The Fugitive offers a compelling plot brought to life by Harrison Ford and an incomparable performance by Tommy Lee Jones. We may have an idea how it's going to end early on, but the thrill is in the ride getting there.

A non stop and smart action thriller with great performances and action set pieces. Harrison Ford is at his frantic best, in one of his best and most memorable roles, as Dr Richard Kimble who is on the run and trying to clear his name. Tommy Lee Jones shines, and quite frankly steals the show, as the determined and duty bound US Marshall. Honestly, this film has always been known as a Harrison Ford vehicle, but it can be argued its a Tommy Lee Jones film. Ford is out to find the truth and stay one step ahead of the US Marshall. He has a simple arc, and little to no character development. Hes still that same guy as he started the film. But it is Tommy Lee Jones who has the best arc. He is trying to catch Ford with no regard for the truth, just the duty of bringing him in. But over the course of the film, gradually works out that this isn't a straight forward job and comes to realise there is something more to this task. I believe, he let Kimble slip through his fingers as much, because he knew he would lead him to the solution of this mystery. He has the best character arc and the best development.
The only thing that goes against this film, is that I waited too long to watch it. It has been parodied and mimicked within an inch of it life. I felt like I had already seen it, from various parodies in The Simpsons and even the Leslie Nielsen film, Wrongfully Accused. For me, this film wasn't as exciting and refreshing to watch, as those who watched it when it came out.  And, to me, thats a shame, that so many film are no longer as enjoyable as they should be, because so many of the best bits have been lifted and shown elsewhere.
This is one of the greatest movies of all time!!! I believe it is my favorite flick.
Really good, kept me wondering throughout
This movie is awesome.
Great cat and mouse film with some amazing plot twists.

This is one of my favorite movies and a great example of amazing filmmaking, it blends a smart and engaging script with swift and precise direction, add on a pair of fantastic performances from Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones and you have one of the top thriller films of all time, and an amazing movie in general. I can't tell you how good Jones and Ford are in this movie, it must be experienced for yourself, they actually don't have too many scenes together, but they carry the entire movie very well when you keep switching back and forth between them. The script tries to keep up with the great performances, not to say that it was bad, it was actually complex and thought-provoking, and there is nothing super unrealistic happening either, this film is very grounded in reality and everyone feels very human and vulnerable. There is also a lot of great intensity and suspense in this film when Ford is on the run, you always get worried, scared even, if he will get caught or escape in spectacular fashion, he's never really safe, he always has to be aware of his surroundings and try and blend in as much as possible, and there is a sense of urgency as well, all of that together makes this a great display of emotions and senses without using any dialogue, this uses the show don't tell method to perfection. The bus crash scene has got to be my favorite, you fear for his life so much, and you actually care about what happens to him, every character developing moment at the very beginning of the film pays off greatly. I also enjoy the mystery aspect of this film, Ford is not only on the run, but he is investigating his wife's murder as well and it adds depth to what he is doing, the script is very well fleshed out from a character development and plot perspective, I was genuinely surprised by how good is and realized it even when I was younger. I can't really think of a more entertaining and engaging thriller than this film, it is a classic in my eyes and I love how rewatchable it is, even when you know what happens, that is thanks to the genuine intensity and pure fear that this film evokes within you. This is a very well written and even better-acted film and is very deserving of high praise.

This dramatic thriller was very good. Harrison Ford, Tommy Lee Jones, and the rest of the cast did a fantastic job in this movie. The plot to the movie was very good, suspenseful, and it had a shocking twist at the end. It's a movie about finding the truth at all costs. This is a movie for everyone. I would definitely recommend it.
In my opinion, it somehow is the best movie Harrison Ford has been in.
Why is the janitor a cop?

The Fugitive is about a Chicago surgeon and a prison escapee, Dr Richard Kimble, who is falsely convicted of murdering his wife and wants to solve his wife's murder by pursuing the real murderer, who is a one armed man whilst being chased by the U.S Marshals and the police. This is my favourite film of all time for so many reasons. Firstly, Harrison Ford is my favourite actor and he gives his best performance in this film as Dr Richard Kimble; Secondly, all of the supporting actors and actresses are truly phenomenal as they give powerful performances but Tommy Lee Jones steals the show as U.S Marshal Sam Gerard which he won an Oscar for Best Actor in a Supporting Role and an Academy Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role and he absolutely deserved those awards; Thirdly, all of the chase scenes and action sequences in this film never lose suspense and intensity which can be a difficult job but it was perfectly executed and lastly, the score in this film is so beautiful and spine-chilling making the atmosphere and every scene so unique and amazing. Andrew Davis is the brains behind this masterpiece which is based of the 1960s TV series 'The Fugitive', he is also the brains behind 'Under Siege' which is one of my favourite films of all time and 9 cast members from 'Under Siege' are in this film including Tommy Lee Jones. I've watched this film so many times now and it never gets boring and I actually enjoy it more every time I watch it which says a lot. Overall, this is an exhilarating film that I highly recommend to people who like Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones, crime films and perfectly made films. What are you waiting for???????? Watch this film if you haven't already!!!!!!!!!!!

Harrison Ford. Tommy Lee Jones.
Great story ✅
Great acting ✅
Great technical work ✅
Great screenplay ✅
Great supporting cast ✅
Great music ✅
A very well done script, a nice twist and with an amazing couple with magnificent performances.
Classic! Ford and Jones at their best!

The fact that this film was nominated for Best Picture displays just how male oriented the membership of the Academy must be as they selected a thriller featuring middle aged men over better popular, mainstream films such as Sleepless in Seattle (1993) and The Age of Innocence (1993). Obviously the film wasn't made for me as I am not an aging father with fears about my own mortality but for the genre it works in this is a decent film by my estimation. While I have never understood the appeal of Harrison Ford as a leading man he is perfectly serviceable here and Tommy Lee Jones gives an Academy Award winning performance as the man on his tail. This isn't one of the best films of 1993, an unusually deep year of cinema, but there are definitely worse choices that could have been made.

Respected vascular surgeon Richard Kimble, Harrison Ford, finds his wife brutally murdered by a mysterious one armed man one night after returning from a convention. He is found guilty of murdering his wife when it is discovered that he is the sole beneficiary of her life insurance policy and is sentenced to death. He escapes from the bus transporting him to death row after other passengers are able to shoot most of the guards on board and an accident occurs. U.S. Marshal Samuel Gerard, Tommy Lee Jones, is assigned to track down Kimble and as Kimble attempts to adopt new identities and hide out in the houses of random people he investigates his wife's murder. Kimble makes several miraculous escapes from his captor and armed with information about men with prosthetic arms he comes closer to absolving himself of his crimes.

There are several thrilling action set pieces in the film that fans of the genre will surely be familiar with as the fast moving train that Ford is barely able to escape, the elevator precariously suspended between floors and the dive into a dramatic dam of our protagonist do make for some tense, exciting moments. These are spaced out between scenes of Ford desperately hiding under a quilt of leaves while hiding out from Jones and correctly diagnosing a young patient in a Chicago hospital. Director Andrew Davis has a knack for keeping the action coming even as the plot is quite obviously ludicrous and the characters aren't as complex and fascinating as they could be. This all adds up to creating an enjoyable yarn which will keep audiences of all types engaged but I still felt that there was something lacking.

I needed to feel Kimble's desperation more than I did as while Ford's shaken expressions and the cheesy flashbacks featuring Sela Ward setting up a romantic homecoming for Ford give us the gist of who Kimble is I wanted more depth. I am not asking for a thirty minute section of the film that is just about Ford loving his wife but perhaps just one scene in which we more firmly establish how important she is to him before she is beaten to death. The court case is then relatively unbelievable as he appears to have no defense and is sentenced almost immediately to death row. Because this is a thriller this is a plot point that you just go along with but considering the amount of prestige attached to the film I expected more. The film also does not lean into the camp that makes a thriller so delightfully an compelling and instead chooses to portray everything with a straight face leaving no room for some of the more offbeat plot points to be interpreted as humorous or deliberately wacky. 

Ford is solid but rather dull as a lead with his Kimble coming across as the same boring, grumpy man he plays in most films and another leading man from this era could have spiced up the film a little bit. Jones is quite impressive as a man with total dedication to his job who begins to stray from his own strict beliefs as he too questions whether his target is innocent or guilty. No, he's not better than Leonardo DiCaprio in What's Eating Gilbert Grape? (1993) or Ralph Fiennes in Schindler's List (1993) but he's good enough to receive special recognition for his work. 

Overall a decent but underwhelming thriller that was overrated during it's time and appears heavily flawed when viewed through a modern perspective.
It's the best movie i ever seen the story is so good
The most thrilling exiting action crime thriller ever with two incredible actors,great screenplay and best director.
The greatest chase film of all-time. There's never a dull moment and it's an incredible thrill ride that stands the test of time.

The Fugitive is a modern classic - it takes the moral obligations of the law as well as a falsely accused ‘fugitive' and melds them together into an action packed, beautifully scripted, intense thriller, which exceeds the watchability and originality of any other. I definitely recommend.
It's got some flaws but it's easy to forgive it thanks to the spectacular performances from the cast (specially Tommy Lee Jones).
Ford is the freight train that's in front of this flick. Tommy Lee Jones is the engineer. Just grab the popcorn and get out of the way.
The movie plot is interesting and Tommy Lee Jones and Harrison Ford are amazing, but it feels very repetitive and at the end you get a little boring.

The Fugitive is one of the most "90's" movies I have seen in awhile. It also happens to be one of the more entertaining films I have seen in a long time. I had a ton of fun watching this movie and will gladly see it again some day in the future. Everything in this movie from the direction, cinematography, script and the excellent score by James Newton Howard screams 90's and reminds me of an era where things were just more simple.

Andrew Davis did a really good job directing this movie, as every scene is filled with tension, but also functions as a build-up for the next sequence. Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are both fantastic in this movie, definitely one of their best performances for both of them, simply outstanding job. John Pantoliano is also excellent here, I think he's one of the most underrated actors out there, not a lot of people talk about him. He was amazing in The Sopranos, The Matrix and also here.

Like I said, this movie just screams 90's, which is not necessarily a bad thing but I think it works both as a positive and a negative for the movie. This is a film that, while watching it, you are instantly reminded of a certain age in cinema and how movies were produced during that time, which is very interesting. However, that also tells me that the film hasn't aged as well as I would have liked. A few lines here and there seem a bit too cheesy and I found the ending to be very predictable, because I think most of the movies produced during this time and considering the tone of the film early on, I knew Harrison Ford was gonna be innocent. It's also kind of obvious that his other doctor friend was somehow involved in the whole crime. And the ending with the reporters asking stuff about the conclusion of the movie, letting us know that the world now knows that Harrison Ford is considered innocent in the public eye.

There were some things that I don't think made a lot of sense. First off, if they wanted to kill Harrison Ford, why did they send a one-armed man? Couldn't they find someone better for the job? I mean the guy was clearly a psycho, since he ended up killing his wife instead of Harrison Ford. And then, how did Harrison Ford get so much money to survive for so long? I believe they mention at some point that it had been a year since he escaped and unless I missed something, the only money he gets is the money he borrows from his evil friend, which I take it it wasn't a lot, since it was only what he had on him at the time. Also, the final fight between the two is just shlock. 

But, even with all its apparent flaws, The Fugitive is a very entertaining movie and I really liked it.
The Fugitive is one of the best action films ever made and the 2nd best film of 1993 behind Groundhog Day.
Such a great example of a Chase Thriller done right
Great Mystery suspense film that is so much fun to watch. Tommy Lee Jones and Harrison Ford are phenomenal.

I can safely say I've seen this numerous times and I love it. I would even pick it as one of if not the best action movies in a long time. Part mystery, part medical drama, all kinds of action, with a break neck speed and it makes the running time seem not that long even though it's over two hours and twenty minutes. I highly recommend this one.
Harrison Ford is Up against the law as “ The Fugitive “ , with a chilling and thrilling mysterious tone.
I've watched this movie 5 times, and I still find it as good as the first time I saw it.

I stand corrected, this is the best movie we watched in school. This is my dad's favorite movie and I can see why. The acting is stupendous from every character and it combines that with a good story and some action. The story is simple but it's what happens in the middle that is great. The best part is that the character's uses common sense, that really impressed me because most of the time they take the hard way to solve a problem. The movie was a bit too long, not because I was bored but because they stretched the story a bit too far. In the end, I was only little confused because I didn't know how they solved the problem. Aside from that, I really enjoyed this movie, it kept me interested each day while we watched it in forensics.

Thrilling, exhilarating and powerfully suspenseful, this action-drama is fueled with what is possibly one of Harrison Fordï¿ 1/2(TM)s greatest performances, attached wonderfully with Tommy Lee Jones in a show-stealer presence, Andrew Davis delivered a highly effective chase flick, with a formula and pace and strongly iconic moments thatï¿ 1/2(TM)ll remain in posterity, The Fugitive is intense, properly directed and positively addictive, making it one of the 90s memorable action flicks.

Andrew Davis is a one trick pony, but man was his best film absolutely astonishing. There is so much tension and excitement going on, you can't turn away for a second. A 90s thriller with astounding atmosphere, great acting, a suspense filled story, and a healthy amount of action to the superb directing. What else is there left to say? Its one of my favorites and I guarantee you'll enjoy watching it again and again.
Breathtaking, amazing performances and storyline that always leaves the audience at the edge of their seats. This is a must watch action film!

This movie - as well as retaining a somewhat unusual storyline - manages to keep up the already high levels of tension throughout. In spite of one relatively unrealistic scene (the waterfall jump, for those who have seen it), it is brilliant, and well acted by Tommy Lee Jones. An absolute classic for me, something I will remember for years to come, and great for anybody who loves action, murder, or even just doesnï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)t know what to watch. It is one of those features that completely relies upon the screenplay and not the concept for no matter how simple it gets its twists and tricks will bedazzle the viewers in each and every frame as it ages on screen. Andrew Davis has done a plausible job as a director but the real game changer in here is the co-writer; Jeb Stuart, who also wrote the infamous Die Hard. Harrison Ford pulls it off like a charm along with a brilliant performance by Tommy Lee Jones which got him a well deserved Oscar for it. The Fugitive has everything in its right place i.e. from gripping screenplay to exhilarating chase sequences (one of the best part of it is that it keeps the audience engaged through these close encounters in the cat and mouse chase), from twisted plot to brilliant performances and from amazing background score (James Newton Howard has as always done a marvelous work in here) to beautiful cinematography.

When the film reaches the climax, that is where it loses much of the suspense and mystery that made the first half so great. If we're talking about my favorite movie just to watch, hands down it would The Fugitive. This is, in my opinion, the most entertaining movie ever made. It is an action-packed, suspenseful game of cat-and-mouse that has us on the edge of our seats all the way up until the closing credits. It is not only fun and entertaining, but intriguing and interesting as well. I don't often site performances as part of the reason for a movie being great, but here it most certainly is. It stars my two favorite actors - Harrison Ford, playing the innocent man on the run after being accused of murdering his wife, and Tommy Lee Jones, the clever, cunning U.S. Marshall on his tail. All the while, Dr. Richard Kimble (Ford) pursues his own investigation into who really killed his wife, the infamous one-armed man. There are so many great, thrilling sequences in this movie, and it is one of the few thrillers to fully deliver on its exciting presence. It creates an atmosphere of fun and tension, and with some of the best and most entertaining performances I've ever seen, this is no doubt one of my all time favorite movies of all time.

Pretty powerful stuff. It's pretty incredible to see just how determined he was to prove that he didn't commit his own wife's murder. Also incredible to see just how smart, sneaky, and clever he was and how he kept slipping away from the marshals.

Often exciting, often funny, often clever and mostly entertaining, The Fugitive doesn't break much new ground, but doesn't overreach. The whole 'simple crime turning into a larger conspiracy' concept has been done countless times, and here it actually bogs the movie down, detracting from the cat and mouse game that lies at its core. Jones is a great supporting actor, inhabiting a character both ruthless and charismatic, and Ford keeps us on his side as the man caught on the wrong side of the law. The bursts of action and chase scenes are fun to watch, but it's nothing overly special, and our grieving hero doesn't seem to care much for the loss of his wife, almost dismissing it completely, which seems pretty callous and unrealistic. He never manages to stay far ahead of Jones, which keeps things taut and our hero constantly on his toes. It's not something I'd rush to see again, but it's a fun, straightforward chase movie that's worth seeing for the 2 lead performances and it's brief bursts of energy.

The 90s was a really good decade for action films, and this is one of the finest of that era.  The two leads are very different types of characters, who play very well off each other.  The extremely well-paced  plot starts them out as adversaries and gradually brings their interests in alignment in a manner that maximizes suspense.  The supporting cast is superb, featuring veteran character actors like Jeroen Krabbé and Joe Pantoliano, and some rising stars, particularly Julianne Moore is an early prominent role.  Andrew Davis, a reliable action director who helmed career peak films for both Chuck Norris and Steven Seagal, does the best work of his career here, especially on a series of action set pieces that are some of the best of the decade.

It's been a few years since Harrison Ford's last big action flick.  In that time, Ford seems to have aged so much.  But that sure as heck doesn't mean that Ford's action days are over!  Perhaps one of his best actions films to date, "The Fugitive" is an excellent action-thriller.  It is exciting and suspenseful.  It is unpredictable and groundbreaking.  And it is an extremely well-written film.

Also great are the main characters in "The Fugitive".  Harrison Ford, of course, gives an outstanding performance as the fugitive Dr. Richard Kimble.  His character is such a likable guy, and Ford's performance really sells it.  And as great as Ford is, I equally enjoyed the performance of Tommy Lee Jones as Deputy Samuel Gerard.  I especially love Jones's charisma and charm.  It provides nice comedic relief to counterbalance Ford's tragic character.

It's movies like this that remind me why I love Harrison Ford.  Ford proves that he is still relevant as an action star.  "The Fugitive" is one of the best action films I've seen in a while and another success in Ford's career.  It's a definite must-see!

Dr Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford), is wrongly convicted of murdering his wife and is sentenced to death. On his way to jail, a fortuitous accident allows him to escape from the police, and begin an investigation into his wife's murder. While also trying to keep one step ahead of a committed team of US Marshals led by Samuel Gerard, played to Oscar-winning perfection by Tommy Lee Jones.

The Fugitive arrived in theaters as part of a new trend in Hollywood to create movies based on popular television shows. And why not? A great story premise no matter where it comes from, is probably going to work on the big screen if given to the right people.

Set during a brisk Chicago winter, the 'Windy City' makes for a great backdrop to this tightly written thriller. Each and every second of this production is either developing great characters, or moving the plot forward. Andrew Davis's direction is unfussy and mostly, just the facts ma'am, but he also allows for the occasional theatrics which stops The Fugitive from ever feeling slow or boring. Making great use of James Newton Howard's excellent score to build character, or to add an extra punch to the action.

The best thing about The Fugitive however, is Harrison Ford. Absolutely convincing as the intelligent and resourceful Dr. Kimble, yet also brings a great vulnerability to the part, as his character mourns the loss of his wife, and runs from the police. Dr Kimble is a man you want to root for. Ford's earnest performance of a wrongly convicted man trying to clear his name, should have even the most cynical moviegoers sweating his troubles, and celebrating his victories!

Movie Prep:

There's not much else I can add that would prepare you for this film. It's a very solidly made well written thriller, and has two memorable performances from Tommy Lee Jones and Harrison Ford.

Best Format:

This is film looks great, and would be well serviced on a theater screen or large TV at home.

Best Moment:

If you ever foolishly doubt the acting talents of Harrison Ford, and think he's only good for bit of swashbuckling fun as Indiana Jones or Han Solo, then watch the scene in this movie where he's being questioned by the police. Watch him slowly get more and more upset as their questions start to insinuate his guilt in the murder of his character's wife, and then tell me he can't act.

Jones is brilliant in his Oscar winning turn as Marshal Sam Jarrad, playing him not as a bad guy but just a dedicated law officer trying to catch his man, whether he's guilty or innocent.  Behind the camera, Twohy & Stuart's script is smart & focused on the main story, with nice nods to the TV show (from Kimbell helping others despite the risk of getting caught to Jarrad's growing doubts about his guilt) while Davis keeps the action move with some brilliant set-pieces (the train crash is even more impressive today giving it was done with practical effects).  Not just a great example of how to adapt a TV show to film but one of the best thrillers ever made.

Based upon the TV series created by Roy Huggins, which ran from 1963 to 1967, this big screen version was directed by Andrew Davies (Under Siege (1992), Chain Reaction (1996) and Holes (2003)) and written by David Twohy (Pitch Black (2000)). This film version manages to capture the spirit of the original series, and it manages to be a great thriller getting the balance just right. Dr. Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford) comes home to find his wife Helen (Sela Ward) being beaten by a one-armed man, and due to a misunderstood phone call, Kimble is sentenced to death. On the way to death row, other prisoners on the bus stage attempt to escape. In the confusion, a train crashes into the bus, but not before Kimble is able to escape. But it's not long before Deputy U.S. Marshal Samuel Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones) is hot on his tail. But, Kimble uses his escape to try and find who framed him for the murder, with help from his old friend Dr. Charles Nichols (Jeroen Krabbé), Kimble goes undercover to find who the one-armed man was. It is a very suspenseful film, and it was one of the few examples of a film version of a classic TV show making a successful transition, it has a very good cast, Jones won an Oscar for his role as the sharp and unstoppable U.S. Marshal, who would return in a sequel called U.S. Marshals 5 years later.
Though it rests on an overdone concept, Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones add an interesting layer of depth and intrigue to this thriller.

When Director Andrew Davis (Under Siege, The Package and Holes) directed The Fugitive, Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones were at the top of their game. You did have Joe Pantoliano, Sela Ward, Jeroen Krabbé (Who?) and even Julianne Moore (surprise, surprise that too in a 3 minute role) add to the flavor - so you can imagine how old this movie was. At that time, the movie was a smashing success. However, when you look at it today, you may not get the same feeling.
Though the storyline is pretty good and the direction of the movie is quite thrilling, certain scenes of the movie come to question:
1. Harrison Fords incredible jump of nearly 300 meter high into the waters - and still surviving it
2. The Entire Police Force not being able to corner one simple doctor?
3. The manner in which Harrison Ford uncovers the mystery of the murder
4. The Improbable nature of how the movie ended.

While you may think these are very small bits to the movie - they actually make you laugh with disbelief and hence make you disconnect from the character, the plot and the movie.

So Moment of Truth
An Entertaining Movie that is good enough for a single watch. It still does have its charm. Especially the Train Crash Scene - which to be honest, I still cannot for the life of me understand what was the point of having it in the movie???

I have seen numerous remakes of classic television series for the Big Screen over the years. Most of them make fun of the original TV series, and many just flop. "The Fugitive" is easily one of the best Big Screen remakes of a classic TV series to date, if not the best in general. 

Vascular surgeon, "Dr. Richard Kimball" (Harrison Ford) is arrested, tried and wrongly convicted for the murder of his wife (Sela Ward, seen in flashbacks) and sentenced to death. 

Some time after being sent to prison, "Dr. Kimball" and other prisoners are being transported to another prison by bus. Minutes pass, and one of the prisoners appears to be having a seizure, making the bus driver stop. As the guards check on the prisoner, a train's horn can be heard coming closer. Suddenly, the bus is hit by the train, killing many, while surviving prisoners escape. One of the survivors is "Dr. Kimball," who pulls a seriously injured guard from the wreck before running. 

The next day, "US Deputy Marshal Samuel 'Big Dog' Gerard" (Tommy Lee Jones) and his team come to the scene of the wreck and discovers that "Dr. Kimball" had survived, and begins to go after him. 

"Deputy Gerard" expects that he is after a convicted murder, but soon learns the truth of "Dr. Kimball's" case by piecing together clues he finds while on the fugitive's trail about the same time "Dr. Kimball" himself is finding clues leading to the same conclusion -- and his innocence. 

The first thing you will notice is that is lots of action and great acting from the main cast. When it comes to the action, the scenes are edited well together, and are spread apart enough so that you will get some time to breathe. 

The next thing you will notice is that the movie, as a whole, is written nicely. There are a few times where the script lags, but there isn't that much lagging. The story is compelling, and you cheer "Dr. Kimball" and "Deputy Gerard" pretty much equally. 

The movie is nicely edited, and shot. Scenes that stand out are action and fight scenes. You will also like the scenes where "Deputy Gerard" and his team are close to capturing their fugitive. The scenes are filled with suspense just as much as action. 

There is a little problem with character development with the supporting cast. Most notably "Deputy Gerard's" team and a few villains. But these flaws are forgettable thanks to the story itself. 

In my opinion, "The Fugitive" is not only a great movie to watch on HBO or Encore, it is also a great selection for a first-choice the next time you go to your local video rental store as well as a good addition to your collection.

The Fugitive is most likely the most recognizable film that Schindler's List tossed aside while cruising to its Best Picture win, as well as being the recipient of the Oscar that probably should have gone to Ralph Fiennes's mesmerizing Amon Goeth of the same movie (even though Tommy Lee Jones was fantastic in this). Going with that, this movie must be very good. And good it is, perhaps even great, but it is not the king of thrillers of the last 20 years that people may say.

The biggest problem I have with the Fugitive is simply that I feel it is slightly long. Its premise and plot is intriguing, but not in depth enough to handle a run time of this caliber. Take off twenty minutes or so, and you've got a fast, breathless thriller that runs smoothly. Instead, the 130 minutes it stands up to makes you feel a little worn out by the end, and not in the good way that it should. 

Other than that, this is an entertaining chase flick. Harrison Ford does his usual action hero thing and Jones is, as I said, fantastic. Besides those two leading the acting charge, there's really nobody else to stand out. Julianne Moore does less than her character does in the movie, and Jorean Krabbe, once a mediocre Bond villain, makes for a mediocre role here as well. However, Ford's and Jones's presence are more than enough to make up for any shortcomings from their screen companions. In addition, the action scenes are well shot and succeed in giving the film some momentum when things get dull during the length. 

While not one of the most incredible thrillers out there, and perhaps not worthy of a Best Picture nomination, The Fugitive does its job to entertain you, even if the length may not keep things movie quite as fast as it should.

Certain people in the Hollywood industry are undeniably cool. Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are both firmly entrenched in that group of performers, and they both put on a brilliant show here.

The highlight, is of course, Tommy Lee Jones' Oscar-winning portrayal of the Deputy Marshall, playing it with such an attitude that he becomes both dour and funny simultaneously (a trait he would later use to great effect as Agent K in "Men in Black")

But Harrison Ford evokes the sympathy of the viewer, as the framed Dr. Kimble, and it's his story that quite fairly drags us into the story.

The action is inspired (particularly a crash between a train and a bus) and when I saw the director, I couldn't believe this fantastic action film came from a man known for Steven Seagal drivel. 

Amazing what a good cast can do, eh?
